<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of answer_shared_response:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
answer_shared_response (void *cls,
                        struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                        const char *url,
                        const char *method,
                        const char *version,
                        const char *upload_data,
                        size_t *upload_data_size,
                        void **req_cls)
{
  static int marker = 0;
  unsigned int resp_index;
  static volatile unsigned int last_index = 0;
  (void) cls;  /* Unused */
  (void) url; (void) version; /* Unused */
  (void) upload_data; (void) upload_data_size; /* Unused */

  if (NULL == *req_cls)
  {
    /* The fist call */
    *req_cls = (void *) ▮
    /* Do not send reply yet. No error. */
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */

  /* This kind of operation does not guarantee that numbers are not reused
     in parallel threads, when processed simultaneously, but this should not
     be a big problem, as it just slow down replies a bit due to
     responses locking. */
  resp_index = (last_index++) % num_resps;
  return MHD_queue_response (connection, MHD_HTTP_OK, resps[resp_index]);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I flagged pointer declarations and the assignment that may need const qualification. I did NOT flag the const-qualified parameters (const char *url, const char *method, const char *version, const char *upload_data) because they already satisfy the rule. I did NOT flag non-pointer objects (marker, last_index, resp_index) or ordinary arithmetic/array indexing lines because Rule 8.13 concerns pointer target const-qualification. I did not mark the call to MHD_queue_response(...) or the use of connection inside it as definitely suspicious because that uses an external API which may legitimately require a non-const pointer; whether connection can be const depends on the API signature (not shown). The listed fragments are the locations in this snippet where a pointer is declared or assigned without const qualification and thus should be investigated to determine whether a const qualification would be appropriate under MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13.
